items.title: Are college students getting too many A's?
items.summary: Harvard University officials have recently raised the alarm on grade inflation. More than 60% of grades awarded to students have been A's. That's up 25% from two decades ago.

items.title: Federal special education staff may get their jobs back. But for how long?
items.summary: A new deal to end the government shutdown may briefly restore staff to U.S. Education Department offices that had been gutted by layoffs.

items.title: For students who rely on SNAP, school food pantries offer some relief
items.summary: A school in Pittsburgh has set up a food pantry for students and their families whose SNAP benefits have been cut or delayed because of the government shutdown.

items.title: For students who rely on SNAP, school food pantries offer some relief
items.summary: The food pantry at Brashear High School is open once a week, and each student gets about five minutes to shop. Any snacks they don't take often go to teachers, to offer to hungry pupils.

items.title: Alaska's public schools can serve as emergency shelters. The buildings are in crisis
items.summary: Alaska's public schools are being used as emergency shelters, though many of the buildings are crumbling.

items.title: Judge says Education Dept. partisan out-of-office emails violated First Amendment
items.summary: A federal judge says the Trump administration "overplayed its hand" by inserting partisan language into workers' out-of-office autoreplies.

items.title: Public workers could be denied loan forgiveness if cities defy Trump, lawsuit alleges
items.summary: A new lawsuit argues the latest changes to Public Service Loan Forgiveness could exclude public servants whose organizations have resisted President Trump's policies.

items.title: A photographer captures life inside Chicago Public Schools
items.summary: Melissa Ann Pinney's photographs capture everyday moments of adolescence inside Chicago Public Schools over the course of a seven-year artist residency.

items.title: Fewer students are missing school. These state policies may have helped
items.summary: A new study says several states are doing the right things to get students to show up to school regularly.

items.title: Shutdown puts thousands of schoolkids at risk of losing Head Start services
items.summary: If the government shutdown isn't resolved by Nov. 1, some 65,000 low-income children will be at-risk of losing access to Head Start child care and early learning.
